instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Good afternoon this mac has suffered oxidation in the <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> regions. I replaced the oxidized components, it worked for a while. The customer returned with the defect of an unexpected shutdown. Now no PPBUS.

I had made a post earlier.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-error-kernel-sleep.61295/[/URL]

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>                    0.487V         1.80v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>                       0,507            3,33v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>              0,520V         0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>                      0,527V        1,82v


    <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
How do you get 20V without <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
This is really strange.

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> 0v"
Check again these voltages; especially when you get 20V at USB-C meter.
If not present, check diode mode to ground on both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
mode diode
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> 0V,no pulse.   0,557V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V, no pulse                     0,370V
FB200 20,11V 

I had changed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> earlier, I forgot to comment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>.
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
So you have problem located in USB-C areas.
More components affected by corrosion.

Post <CAPACITOR>C3101</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Connect charger to its corresponding port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Suddenly the mac turned on using another charger. 
I left it in tests and out of nowhere it turned off and won't turn on anymore. It is intermittent, out of nowhere it turns on. 
   I would like to know if the components I already replaced are <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3906</CHIP>, <CHIP>U4401</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5850</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> ? 


PPBUS 12,6V
